app.title: an anthropocene river
app.name: Mississippi
app.meta_description: This map documents a regional project linked to the Anthropocene Curriculum program organized by Haus der Kulturen der Welt and the Max Planck Institute, Berlin.

attrs.value: Receive email updates on your report

content: Project participants at the kickoff event in Minneapolis, June 2018

This map is devoted to contemporary "Life on the Mississippi," in an era when all that once seemed familiar keeps changing day by day. The images of the old river—celebrated in music, movies and the writings of Mark Twain—have given way to something different, a lot stranger and more complex, the new river of our time.

The map is part of an art and research program entitled Mississippi: An Anthropocene River, which springs from an exceptional collaboration between German and American institutions. The aim is to understand the current ecological and social conditions of the great river and its far-flung watersheds, and to express the manifold natures and cultures of its endless flow. Therefore we have put advanced cartography and scientific research into something like a geo-blog, open to highly diverse inputs. It allows those who care about the river to add their words, their images, their knowledge and their unanswered questions. By using the map, you can contribute to an experiment in collective perception.

The map works with conventional Internet browsers and mobile phones. To put something on it is easy: just zoom into the place that interests you and press the big orange button. You'll be asked to drag the map around until the yellow pin falls precisely on the spot, and then to choose one of five categories: Geology, History, Industry, Culture or Ecology. Once you have chosen, a window will appear. That one's for you.

You can enter a title and a text, and by using the little buttons in the editor you can add an image, a link, or the URL of a video that has been uploaded to YouTube or Vimeo. You can also contribute a text and image directly from your mobile phone. It's important to "sign in" first, by clicking the button at upper right, because then you'll be able to edit your post later on. The map is an open archive, placing your experience and understanding alongside others. Feel free to use it in wildly divergent ways.
Abandoned Mississippi River Model, near Jackson, MS

The map/archive will also tell you about the artworks and research projects carried out by those most closely involved in this adventure. To find out about them, just hit "Field Stations." Each of the images you will see is linked to particular areas along the river, where groups of artists and researchers have organized their own exploratory activities. Click on the icons to find out what they have been up to, and zoom in further to gain insights about their territories.

In addition to that, you can open a longer menu by clicking on the little red arrow on the right-hand side (it only appears on larger screens, not on cell phones). There, the same field stations are interspersed with a growing number of thematic maps. These thematic maps showcase different cartographic techniques and forms of scientific or cultural research, all dealing with questions of political ecology. In other words, they show situations where social life is affected by the environment, and vice-versa.

This whole project has been sparked by the concept of the Anthropocene. It describes an era in which humanity has gained quasi-geological powers, capable of reshaping the land, the rivers and the atmosphere. These tremendous powers are often quite familiar: they can be seen in the locks, the dams, the levees, the earth-moving equipment along the shore, and above all, in the monocrop agriculture that has filled the former floodplains, offering prosperous livelihoods to millions of people. However, these familiar powers of science and industry have more recently become strange, producing unwanted consequences like hypoxic "dead zones" in the ocean or runway climate change. As the largest drainage basin in North America, the Mississippi-Missouri-Ohio River watershed offers a tangible example of conditions affecting the entire earth system.

Does anyone really know what's happening? We are plumbing unknown waters in this project, a bit like Mark Twain on the old Mississippi, sounding the depths for dangerous shoals. It took some courage to pilot a steamboat in those days.
Go ahead, join us in this adventure. The idea is to sound out the new river, and beyond it, the unknown world we all share.
White Pelicans in the current at the Sidney A. Murray Jr. Hydroelectric Station, Louisiana

If you experience a problem editing your posts, it's probably because an older copy of the website is cached in your browser. Try refreshing the page, or use the ctrl-F5 key combination, or clear your recent history and that will likely solve the problem.

This project uses custom raster tiles produced by the primary map editor Brian Holmes, drawing on the USDA's 2018 Cropland Data Layer in particular. Roadways and other overlay information come from a specially configured Mapbox layer based on Open Street Map files. Areas outside the Mississippi watershed display ESRI's World Ocean map, and deep zooms reveal the same company's World Imagery layer, both of which are based on US government public domain sources. Lakes, rivers and those wonderful hotspots of biodiversity called swamps have been precisely mapped by the National Wetlands Inventory. Levees, represented by orange lines that appear when you zoom in, come from the Army Corps of Engineers National Levee Database. Like many other features in the rest of the map, the levee lines deliver additional information when you click on them.

The software that makes all the interaction and community input possible has been developed by a Seattle-based group called Mapseed. Contact them if you want to do this type of project! Any mistaken or misleading information on this map is undoubtedly due to the limited understanding of the editors, sorry. Tell us about it and we'll fix it.
Canoes set out from Lake Itasca. Field stations greet them along the river. It all culminates with an Anthropocene Campus in New Orleans.
Click the images for artworks, research and events. Open the panel on the right for additional thematic maps. Add your own material if you feel it.
